summary: E.O. Wilson is a biologist and winner of the 2007 Ted Prize. Wilson: "If we were to wipe out insects alone, just that group alone on this planet, which we are trying hard to do, the rest of life and humanity with it"
transcript: Ted Toxer recorded live at the Ted Conference and produced with WNYC New York Public Radio. This episode features biologist E.O. Wilson, winner of the 2007 Ted Prize. Ted Toxer made possible through the support of BMW. Here's E.O. Wilson. Please keep in mind that if we were to wipe out insects alone, just that group alone on this planet, which we are trying hard to do, the rest of life and humanity with it would mostly disappear from the land and within a few months. So how did I come to this particular position of advocacy? As a little boy through my teenage years, I became increasingly fascinated by the diversity of life. I had a butterfly period, a snake period, a bird period, a fish period, a cave period, and finally, and definitively, an ant period. By my college years, I was a devoted mermicologist, a specialist on the biology of ants, but my attention and research continued to make journeys across the great variety of life on Earth in general, including all that it means to us as a species, how little we understand it, and how pressing a danger that our activities has created for it. Out of that broader study has emerged a concern and an ambition crystallized in the wish that I'm about to make to you.

summary: "I was enchanted by the natural beauty of that region and the almost tropical exuberance of the plants and animals that grow there," he says. "I never considered anything else in my entire life"
transcript: My choice is the culmination of a lifetime commitment that began with growing up on the Gulf Coast of Alabama and the Florida Peninsula. As far back as I can remember, I was enchanted by the natural beauty of that region and the almost tropical exuberance of the plants and animals that grow there. One day when I was only seven years old and fishing, I pulled a pinfish, they're called, with sharp, dorsal spines, up too hard and fast, and I blinded myself in one eye. I later discovered I was also hard of hearing, possibly congenitally, in the upper registers. I had to go and planning to be a professional naturalist. I never considered anything else in my entire life.

transcript: I found that I was a lousy at bird watching and couldn't track frog calls either, so I returned to the teaming small creatures that can be held between the thumb and forefinger. I found all the things that compose the foundation of our ecosystems, the little things that I like to say who run the world. In so doing, I reached the frontier of biology so strange, so rich that it seemed as though it exists on another planet. We live on a mostly unexplored planet. The great majority of organisms on Earth remain unknown to science. In the last 30 years, thanks to explorations and remote parts of the world and advances in technology, biologists have for example added a full one-third of the known frog and other amphibian species to bring the current total to 5,400 and more continue to pour in. Two new kinds of whales have been discovered along with two new adelopes, dozens of monkey species and a new kind of elephant, and even a distinct kind of gorilla. At the extreme opposite end of the size scale, the class of marine bacteria, the pro-chlorococci, that will be on the final exam. Although discovered only in 1988, they're now recognized as likely the most abundant organisms on Earth, and moreover responsible for a large part of the photosynthesis that occurs in the ocean. These bacteria were not uncovered sooner because they are also among the smallest of all Earth's organisms, so minute that they cannot be seen with conventional optical microscopy, yet life in the sea may depend on these tiny creatures. These examples are just the first glimpse of our ignorance of life on this planet. Consider the fungi, including mushrooms, rust, moles, and many disease-causing organisms. Sixty thousand species are known to science, but more than 1.5 million have been estimated to exist. Consider the nematode around worms, the most abundant of all animals. 4 out of 5 animals on Earth are nematode worms. If all solid material, except nematode worms were to be eliminated, you could still see the ghostly outline of most of it in nematode worms. About 16,000 species of nematode worms have been discovered and diagnosed by scientists. There could be hundreds of thousands of them, even millions still unknown. transcript: Finally, we get this underway seriously. As we move past the relatively gigantic mammal, birds, frogs and plants, to the more elusive insects and other small invertebrates, and then beyond, to the countless millions of organisms in the invisible living world that envelop live within humanity. Already, what we are thought to be bacteria for generations have been found to compose instead two great domains of microorganisms, the true bacteria, and one cell organisms, they are chaos, which are closer than are the bacteria to the eukaryo, the group that we belong to. Some serious biologists and I count myself among them have begun to wonder that among the enormous and still unknown diversity of microorganisms, one might. Just might find aliens among them. True aliens, stocks that arrive from outer space, they've had billions of years to do it. But especially during the earliest period of biological evolution on this planet, we do know that some bacterial species that have earthly origin are capable of almost unimaginable extremes of temperature and other harsh changes in environments including hard radiation strong enough and maintained long enough to crack the pyrex vessel around the growing population of bacteria. There may be a temptation to treat the biosphere holistically, and the species that compose it as a great flux of entities, hardly worth distinguishing one from the other. But each of these species, even the tiniest of the four mentioned pro-chlorococci are masterpieces of evolution. Each has persisted for thousands to millions of years. Each is exquisitely adapted to the environment in which it lives, interlocked with other species to form the ecosystems upon which our own lives depend in ways we have not begun even to imagine. We will destroy these ecosystems and the species, composing them at the peril of our own existence, and unfortunately we are destroying them with ingenuity and ceaseless energy.

transcript: My own epiphany as a conservationist came in 1953 while a Harvard graduate student searching for rare ants found in the mountain forest of Cuba, ants that shine in the sunlight, metallic green or metallic blue according to species, and one species I discovered metallic gold. I found my magical ants, but only after a tough climb into the mountains where the last of the 80s Cuban forest hung on, hung on, and were then and still are being cut back. I realized then that these species, in a large part of the other unique, marvellous animals and planetes of that island, and this is true of practically every part of the world, which took millions of years to evolve or in the process of disappearing forever, and so it is everywhere one looks. The human juggernaut is permanently eroding earth, ancient biosphere, by a combination of forces that can be summarized by the acronym HIPPO, the animal HIPPO. H is for habitat destruction, including climate change forced by greenhouse gases. I is for the invasive species like the ants, the fire ants, the zebra mussels and the brome grasses, and pathogenic bacteria and viruses that are flooding every country and that an exponential rate.

transcript: That's the eye. The P, the first one in HIPPO is for pollution. The second is for continued population, human population expansion, and the final letter of O is for overharvesting driving species into extinction by excessive hunting and fishing. The HIPPO juggernaut we have created, if unabated, is destined according to the best estimates of ongoing biodiversity research to reduce half of earth still surviving animal and plant species to extinction or critical endangerment by the end of the century. Human force climate change alone, again, if unabated, could eliminate a quarter of surviving species during the next five decades. What will we and all future generations lose if much of the living environment is thus degraded? Huge potential sources of scientific information yet to be gathered, much of our environmental stability and new kinds of pharmaceuticals and new products of unimaginable strength and value all thrown away. transcript: That's in the United States. We are in short flying blind into our environmental future. We urgently need to change this. So this brings me to my wish for Tedsters and to anyone else around the world who hears this talk. I wish we will work together to help create the key tools that we need to inspire preservation of biodiversity. And let us call it the Encyclopedia of Life. What is the Encyclopedia of Life? A concept that has already taken hold and is beginning to spread and be looked at seriously. It is an Encyclopedia that lives on the internet and is contributed to by thousands of scientists around the world. Amateurs can do it also. It has an indefinitely expandable page for each species. I have written about this idea before and I know there are people in this room who have expanded, or how expanded, significant effort on it in the past. But what excites me is that since I first put forward this particular idea in that form, science has advanced technology has moved forward. Today the practicalities of making such an Encyclopedia regardless of the magnitude of the information put into it are within reach. I have made reality within reach. Indeed in the past year a group of influential scientific institutions have begun mobilizing to realize this dream. I wish you would help them. Working together we can make this real. The Encyclopedia will quickly pay for itself in practical applications. It will address transcendent qualities in the human consciousness and sense of human need. It will transform the science of biology and ways of obvious benefit to humanity. And most of all it can inspire a new generation of biologists to continue the quest that started for me personally 60 years ago to search for life, to understand it, and finally above all to preserve it.
